webTitle: Gas suppliers used market restructure to hike prices, watchdog says

fields.bodyText: Gas suppliers on the east coast of Australia have used a market restructure to hike prices on domestic consumers and there is evidence pipeline operators have set monopoly prices, the competition watchdog has said. The lack of competition in gas supply even warrants consideration of whether joint marketing by one of the largest suppliers, the Gippsland Basin joint venture between Esso Australia and BHP Billiton Petroleum, has substantially lessened competition. These are conclusions of the the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission inquiry into the competitiveness of the east coast gas market released on Friday. The inquiry was sparked by complaints from Australian industry that from 2012 they could not get offers for gas supply for 2016 and beyond or received few offers at high prices. At the time gas was increasingly being liquified for export to international markets, decreasing supply for domestic industry. The ACCC has backed up these complaints, finding Australian industry received “few, if any, real offers for gas”, including offers being “at sharply higher prices and on strict take it or leave it terms”. “There are now more gas supply offers available in the market but they are from fewer sources of supply, higher priced, often for shorter durations and with tighter non-price terms and conditions. Other problems also remain in the market.” The ACCC found that the Gippsland Basin joint venture “holds significant market power” and its joint marketing “may have a more detrimental impact on competition than in the past”. The competition watchdog will now investigate whether the joint marketing substantially lessens competition, in breach of the Competition and Consumer Act. The ACCC said more sources of gas are needed, particularly in the southern states, as they are becoming “overly dependent” on the joint venture. A spokeswoman for BHP Billiton Petroleum said: “The company believes supply by the [joint venture] to the east coast gas market is competitive and is effectively meeting the requirement of gas buyers currently and will continue to do so into the future. “The company will continue to work with the ACCC on this matter, as it has done throughout the course of the inquiry.” The Australian Industry Group chief executive, Innes Willox, said the report showed the gas market is opaque, there are significant risks to supply and that the competitive dynamics south of Queensland are deteriorating considerably. “Gas plays a critical role as a feedstock and an efficient source of heat and power to industry,” he said. “Gas users have been raising the alarm for several years about the impact of massive change in the market on industry and the consequences for investment and jobs.” Willox said: “Maximising effective competition in the market is crucial, whether it involves bringing on new suppliers or changing the dynamics between existing suppliers.” The ACCC rejected calls to reserve a proportion of Australia’s gas for domestic use, as has been suggested by the Australian Workers Union. It said such a policy would reduce domestic prices in the short term but weaken incentives to explore and extract more gas “to the detriment of the level and diversity of supply for domestic gas users”. Instead the ACCC recommended requiring industry to provide better information about price and availability of gas supply to increase transparency for consumers. A spokesman for the AWU said the argument about extraction investment was a “furphy” and highly theoretical, when experience showed showed Australia could use its gas reserves to provide local consumers with cheap, relatively green energy. “Greater price transparency would be a plus, but even better would be a national interest test, akin to the US or Canada, or, better still, a gas reservation policy.” The ACCC also found evidence that a large number of existing gas pipeline operators had been engaging in monopoly pricing. Evidence included special charges and revenues in excess of what would be expected if pipelines were regulated sufficiently. It noted monopoly pricing was not a breach of the law and said it was a “legitimate and expected commercial behaviour”. “Monopoly pricing can, nevertheless, have a detrimental effect on economic efficiency and consumers.” Pipelines with substantial market power should be subject to greater regulation, and be forced to publish financial information so customers can determine whether the prices are justified by the pipeline’s costs, it recommended. The ACCC will also consider whether the availability or pricing of capacity on regional pipelines constitutes misuse of market power. The assistant treasurer, Kelly O’Dwyer, said the ACCC had established the facts in the gas market after the confidential nature of contracts, prices and negotiations had hampered the ability of previous reviews to disentangle and test the assertions about the market. The energy and resources minister, Josh Frydenberg, said the report showed “that unless the commonwealth and state governments work together to address supply-side constraints, consumers and industry will bear the cost of higher gas prices and less reliable supply”. The Council of Australian Governments energy council will discuss the report in a video conference.
